Automatica

Volume 84, October 2017, Pages 26-35

Tensor Network alternating linear scheme for MIMO Volterra system identification☆

Author links open overlay panel, ,
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.automatica.2017.06.033Get rights and content
Full text access

Abstract

This article introduces two Tensor Network-based iterative algorithms for the identification of high-order discrete-time nonlinear multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) Volterra systems. The system identification problem is rewritten in terms of a Volterra tensor, which is never explicitly constructed, thus avoiding the curse of dimensionality. It is shown how each iteration of the two identification algorithms involves solving a linear system of low computational complexity. The proposed algorithms are guaranteed to monotonically converge and numerical stability is ensured through the use of orthogonal matrix factorizations. The performance and accuracy of the two identification algorithms are illustrated by numerical experiments, where accurate degree-10 MIMO Volterra models are identified in about 1 s using Matlab on a 3.3 GHz quad-core desktop computer with 16 GB RAM.

  • Next article in issue

Keywords

Volterra series
Tensors
MIMO
Identification methods

1. Introduction

Volterra series (Wiener, Stratton, & Technology, 2013) have been extensively studied and applied in applications like speech modeling (Mumolo & Francescato, 1993), loudspeaker linearization (Kajikawa, 2008), nonlinear control (Pearson, & Ogunnaike, 2002), active noise control (Tan & Jiang, 2001), modeling of biological and physiological systems (Korenberg & Hunter, 1996), nonlinear communication channel identification (Fernandes, Mota, & Favier, 2010) and equalization (Cheng & Powers, 2001), distortion analysis (Wambacq & Sansen, 1998) and many others. Their applicability has been limited however to “weakly nonlinear systems”, where the nonlinear effects play a non-negligible role but are dominated by the linear term. This limitation is not inherent to the Volterra series themselves, as they can represent a wide range of nonlinear dynamical systems, but is due to the exponentially growing number of Volterra kernel coefficients as the degree increases. Indeed, assuming a finite memory M, the response of a degree-d discrete-time single-input single-output (SISO) Volterra system is given by (1)y(t)=h0+∑i=1d∑k1,…,ki=0M−1hi(k1,…,ki)∏j=1iu(t−kj),where y(t),u(t) are the scalar output and input at time t respectively and the ith-order Volterra kernel hi(k1,…,ki) is described by Mi numbers. For example, storage of the 10th-order Volterra kernel when M=10 and d=10 requires about 75 GB of memory. For a multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) Volterra system with p inputs the situation gets even worse, where the ith-order Volterra kernel for one particular output is characterized by (pM)i numbers. This is one particular example of the problem that is also commonly known as the curse of dimensionality.
The paradigm used in this article to break this curse is to trade storage for computation. This means that all the Volterra coefficients are replaced by only a few numbers, from which all Volterra coefficients can be computed. This idea is not new, e.g. Volterra kernels have been expanded on orthonormal basis functions in order to reduce their complexity Campello et al. (2004), Diouf et al. (2012). Tensors (namely, multi-dimensional arrays that are generalizations of matrices to higher orders) are also suitable candidates for this purpose. In Favier, Kibangou, and Bouilloc (2012) both the canonical polyadic Carroll & Chang (1970), Harshman (1970) and Tucker tensor decompositions (Tucker, 1966) were used. However, the canonical polyadic decomposition can suffer from numerical instability, due to the ill-posedness of the problem of finding a best rank-r approximation (de Silva & Lim, 2008), and the determination of its rank is known to be an NP-hard problem (Håstad, 1990). The main disadvantage of the Tucker decomposition of the Volterra kernels is that it still suffers from an exponential complexity. Note that a Tucker decomposition with orthogonal factor matrices, like for example the higher-order singular value decomposition (Lathauwer, Moor, & Vandewalle, 2000), is in fact an expansion of the Volterra kernels onto a set of orthonormal basis functions.
This motivates us to develop and introduce a new description of discrete-time MIMO Volterra systems in terms of particular Tensor Networks (TN) (Orus, 2014). For the particular case of multiple-input–single-output (MISO) systems, these Tensor Networks will turn out to be Trains (TTs) (Oseledets, 2011b). A TN representation does not suffer from any numerical instability or exponential complexity and can represent all Volterra kernels combined by O(d(pM+1)r2) elements, where r is a to-be-determined number called the TN-rank. TNs were originally developed in the physics community. Of particular importance is the Density Matrix Renormalization Group (DMRG) algorithm (White, 1992), which is an iterative algorithm originally developed for the determination of the ground state of an entangled multi-body quantum system. Its applicability however is not limited to problems in quantum physics, as demonstrated by recent interest in the scientific computing Holtz et al. (2012), Oseledets (2011a), Rohwedder & Uschmajew (2013) and machine learning Chen et al. (2016), Novikov et al. (2015), Novikov et al. (2016) communities.
In this article, we adopt the DMRG method in the TN format for the identification of MIMO discrete-time Volterra systems. The contributions of this article are twofold:
  • (1)
    we derive a new description of discrete-time MIMO Volterra systems using the TN format,
  • (2)
    we derive two iterative MIMO Volterra identification algorithms that estimate all Volterra kernels in the TN format from given input–output data.
In each step of the iterative identification a small linear system needs to be solved. The main computational tools are the singular value decomposition (SVD) and the QR decomposition (Golub & Van Loan, 1996). These orthogonal matrix factorizations ensure the numerical stability of the methods (Holtz et al., 2012). The first identification method, which is called the Alternating Linear Scheme (ALS) method, has the lowest computational complexity but assumes that the TN-ranks rk’s are fixed. The second identification method, called the Modified Alternating Linear Scheme (MALS), removes this limitation and allows for the adaptive updating of the TN-ranks during the iterations. The TN-ranks are determined numerically by means of a SVD. This is reminiscent of the determination of the order of linear systems in subspace identification algorithms (Katayama, 2005). Monotonic convergence of both the ALS and MALS methods under certain conditions is discussed in Rohwedder and Uschmajew (2013).
The outline of this article is as follows. In Section 2 we give a brief overview of important tensor concepts, operations and properties. The MIMO Volterra TN framework is introduced in Section 3. The two iterative identification algorithms are derived in Section 4 and applied on four examples in Section 5. In addition, we compare our proposed method with the identification method of the tensor-based Volterra-PARAFAC model (Favier et al., 2012). To our knowledge, this is the only time where MIMO Volterra systems of degree 10 were identified in about 1 s using Matlab on a 3.3 GHz quad-core desktop computer with 16 GB RAM. Matlab/Octave implementations of our algorithms are freely available from https://github.com/kbatseli/MVMALS.

2. Preliminaries

2.1. Tensor basics

Tensors in this article are multi-dimensional arrays that generalize the notions of vectors and matrices to higher orders. A d-way or dth-order tensor is denoted as A∈Rn1×n2×⋯×nd and hence each of its entries ai1i2⋯id is determined by d indices. The numbers n1,n2,…,nd are called the dimensions of the tensor. A tensor is cubical if all its dimensions are equal. A cubical tensor is symmetric when all its entries satisfy ai1i2⋯id=aπ(i1,i2,…,id), where π(i1,i2,…,id) is any permutation of the indices. For practical purposes, only real tensors are considered. We use boldface capital calligraphic letters A,B,… to denote tensors, boldface capital letters A,B,… to denote matrices, boldface letters a,b,… to denote vectors, and Roman letters a,b,… to denote scalars. The transpose of a matrix A or vector a is denoted by AT and aT, respectively. The unit matrix of order n is denoted as In.
We now give a brief description of some required tensor operations and properties. Unless otherwise stated, all basic tensor operations and properties are from Kolda and Bader (2009). The generalization of the matrix–matrix multiplication to tensors involves a multiplication of a matrix with a d-way tensor along one of its d possible modes.

Definition 2.1

Tensor k-Mode Product

The k-mode product B=A×kU of a tensor A∈Rn1×⋯×nk×⋯×nd with a matrix U∈Rpk×nk is defined by (2)bi1⋯ik−1jik+1⋯id=∑ik=1nkujikai1⋯ik−1ikik+1⋯id,and B∈Rn1×⋯×nk−1×pk×nk+1×⋯×nd.
An interesting observation is that the definition of the k-mode product also includes the multiplication of a tensor A with d vectors. The following definition highlights a very important case.

Definition 2.2

Qi (2005, p. 1303)

Consider a symmetric d-way tensor A with dimensions n and a vector x∈Rn. The multidimensional contraction of A with x=x1x2⋯xnTis the scalar (3)Axd≔A×1xT×2xT×3⋯×dxT,which is obtained as a homogeneous polynomial of degree d in the variables x1,…,xn.
The Kronecker product plays a crucial role in our description of MIMO Volterra systems.

Definition 2.3 Kronecker Product

If B∈Rm1×m2 and C∈Rn1×n2, then their Kronecker product B⊗C is the m1n1×m2n2 matrix (4)b11⋯b1m2⋮⋱⋮bm11⋯bm1m2⊗C=b11C⋯b1m2C⋮⋱⋮bm11C⋯bm1m2C.
We use the notation x≔x⊗x⊗⋯⊗x for the d-times repeated Kronecker product. The mixed-product property of the Kronecker product states that if A,B,C and D are matrices of such sizes that one can form the matrix products AC and BD, then (5)(A⊗B)(C⊗D)=AC⊗BD.

Definition 2.4 Reshaping

Reshaping is another often used tensor operation. The most common reshaping is the matricization, which reorders the entries of A into a matrix. We adopt the Matlab/Octave reshape operator “reshape(A,[n1,n2,n3⋯])”, which reshapes the d-way tensor A into a tensor with dimensions n1×n2×⋯×nd. The total number of elements of A must be the same as n1×n2×⋯×nd.
The mode-n matricization of a tensor A maps its entries ai1i2⋯id to the matrix element with row index in and column index 1+∑k=1,k≠dd(ik−1)∏l=1,l≠dk−1nl.

Example 1

We illustrate the reshaping operator on the 4 ×3 ×2 tensor A that contains all entries from 1 up to 24. Its mode-1 matricization is A(1)=reshape(A,[4,6])=159131721261014182237111519234812162024.
Probably the most important reshaping of a tensor is its vectorization.

Definition 2.5 Vectorization

The vectorization of a tensor A, denoted as vec(A), rearranges all its entries into one column vector indexed by i1+∑k=2d(ik−1)∏l=1k−1nl.

Example 2

For the tensor of Example 1, we have vec(A)=reshape(A,[24,1])=12⋯24T.
The importance of the vectorization lies in the following equation (6)vec(A×1U1×2⋯×dUd)=(Ud⊗⋯⊗U1)vec(A).Observe how the order in the Kronecker product is reversed with respect to the ordering of the mode products. Eq. (6) allows us to rewrite (3) as (7)Axd=vec(A)Tx,which tells us how the k-mode products of a tensor A with a vector x can be computed. When A in (6) is also a matrix, we then obtain the following useful property (8)vec(U1AU2T)=(U2⊗U1)vec(A).

2.2. Tensor train decomposition

The Tensor Network representation used in this article lies conceptually very close to the Tensor Train decomposition (Oseledets, 2011b). We therefore first discuss the Tensor Train representation. A TT-decomposition represents a d-way tensor A in terms of d 3-way tensors A(1),…,A(d), which are called the TT-cores. The kth TT-core has dimensions rk−1,nk,rk, where rk−1,rk are called the TT-ranks. Specifically, each entry of A∈Rn1×⋯×nd is determined by (9)ai1i2⋯id=Ai1(1)Ai2(2)⋯Aid(d),where Aik(k) is the rk−1×rk matrix obtained from specifying the second index ik. An alternative notation for Aik(k) using the Matlab convention is A(k)(:,ik,:). Since ai1i2⋯id is a scalar, it immediately follows that r0=rd=1. The TT-decomposition is illustrated for a 3-way tensor in Fig. 1. Note that when all TT-ranks are equal to r, then the storage of a cubical d-way tensor with dimensions n in the TT format needs O(dnr2) elements. Small TT-ranks therefore result in a significant reduction of required storage cost. The TT-ranks of any given tensor are upper bounded as described by the following theorem.

Theorem 2.1

Theorem 2.1 of Oseledets and Tyrtyshnikov (2010)

For any tensor A∈Rn1×⋯×nd there exists a TT-decomposition with TT-ranks rk≤min∏i=1kni,∏i=k+1dni, for k=1,…,d−1.
We call the values of rk such that the TT representation is exact the canonical TT-ranks. When the values of rk are smaller than the canonical ranks, then the corresponding TT is an approximation of the original tensor A. It is shown in Oseledets (2013) that the TT-representation of particular functions can be written down explicitly and has small canonical ranks. Knowing upper bounds for the canonical TT-ranks is useful when one is required to specify the TT-ranks in the ALS algorithm, as discussed in Sections 4 MIMO Volterra system identification, 5 Numerical experiments. The symmetry of a tensor can be explicitly exploited in a polyadic decomposition, as the mode vectors can all be chosen the same over all modes. Unfortunately, there is no obvious way to exploit the symmetry of the underlying tensor with a TT-decomposition. This, however, is not really a disadvantage since all operations on the TT-cores are still of small computational complexity.
In order to describe MIMO Volterra systems, we will need to remove the constraint that r0=1 and therefore obtain a slightly more general TN. Observe that the removal of this constraint implies that the left-hand side of (9) will then be a r0×1 vector. The following multidimensional contraction in the TN format turns out to be very important for Volterra systems.

Lemma 2.1

Oseledets (2011b, p. 2309)

Given a cubical tensor A∈Rn×⋯×n in the TT format and a vector x∈Rn. The multidimensional contraction Axd can then be computed as (10)Axd=(A(1)×2xT)(A(2)×2xT)⋯(A(d)×2xT).
Note that the dimension of A(1) is 1×n×r1, which implies that A(1)×2xT is a 1×r1 row vector. Similarly, all contractions A(k)×2xT for k=2,…,d−1 result in rk−1×rk matrices. Finally, the contraction on the last TT-core A(d) results in a rd−1×1 column vector. The expression in (10) therefore corresponds with the product of a row vector with matrices and a column vector, resulting in the scalar Axd. In the MIMO case, the contraction (10) results in a r0×1 vector where now each entry is the evaluation of a polynomial.
The numerical stability of the two identification algorithms described in this article relies on the TN-cores being either left or right orthogonal. This orthogonality of the TT-cores ensures that the condition numbers of the linear systems during identification remain uniformly bounded (Holtz et al., 2012 p. A701) and are obtained through the use of either QR or SVD operations.

Definition 2.6

Left-Orthogonal and Right-Orthogonal TN-Cores (Holtz et al., 2012 p. A689)

A TN-core A(i) is left-orthogonal if it can be reshaped into an ri−1ni×ri matrix A for which ATA=Iriapplies. Similarly, a TN-core A(i) is right-orthogonal if it can be reshaped into an ri−1×niri matrix A for which AAT=Iri−1applies.

3. Tensor description of MIMO Volterra systems

To keep the notation simple, we first recall the discrete-time SISO Volterra system of degree d, namely, y(t)=h0+∑i=1d∑k1,…,ki=0M−1hi(k1,…,ki)∏j=1iu(t−kj),where y(t),u(t) are the scalar output and input at time t respectively, M is the memory length and hi(k1,…,ki) denotes the ith Volterra kernel. Previous work that uses tensors in Volterra series describes each separate Volterra kernel as a symmetric tensor Favier & Bouilloc (2009), Favier et al. (2012). In this article, realizing that y(t) is a multivariate polynomial in u(t),…,u(t−M+1), we collect all kernel coefficients into one Volterra tensor. Before giving the definition of the SISO Volterra tensor, we first present the following illustrative example.

Example 3

Consider a discrete-time SISO Volterra system of degree d=3 and with a memory M=2 described by y(t)=h0+h1(0)u(t)+h1(1)u(t−1)+h2(0,0)u(t)2+2h2(1,0)u(t)u(t−1)+h2(1,1)u(t−1)2(11)+h3(0,0,0)u(t)3+3h3(1,0,0)u(t)2u(t−1)+3h3(1,1,0)u(t)u(t−1)2+h3(1,1,1)u(t−1)3,where we explicitly assume that all Volterra kernels are symmetric. An alternative way to write (11) is (12)y(t)=(ut)Tvwith ut≔1u(t)u(t−1)T∈R3and where v∈R27 contains the kernel coefficients h0h1(0)3⋯h2(0,0)3⋯h3(1,1,0)h3(1,1,1)T.Note that some kernel coefficients are repeated in v, due to the multiple entries in ut. We now define the tensor V≔reshape(v,[3,3,3]). It can be verified that V is a symmetric tensor that allows us to rewrite (12) as y(t)=Vut3,where the notation of (3) is used.
This leads us to the following definition.

Definition 3.1 SISO Volterra Tensor

Given a discrete-time SISO Volterra system of degree d and memory M as described in (1), then the d-way cubical Volterra tensor V∈R(M+1)×⋯×(M+1) is defined by y(t)=Vutd,where ut≔1u(t)u(t−1)⋯u(t−M+1)T∈RM+1.
The extension of this definition to the MIMO case is straightforward. Indeed, the ith output yi(t) is then a multivariate polynomial of degree d in u1(t),…,u1(t−M+1),u2(t),…,u2(t−M+1),…,up(t−M+1). This implies that the vector ut in Definition 3.1 needs to be extended with these additional inputs, which results in an increase in the dimension of the corresponding Volterra tensor. In addition, the order of the Volterra tensor is incremented to accommodate for the multiple number of outputs.

Definition 3.2 MIMO Volterra Tensor

Given a discrete time p-input l-output Volterra system of degree d and memory M, then the (d+1)-way Volterra tensor V of dimensions l×(pM+1)×⋯×(pM+1) is defined by (13)y(t)≔y1(t)y2(t)⋮yl(t)=V×2utT×3utT⋯×d+1utT,where ut is the (pM+1)×1 vector with entries 1,u1(t),u2(t),…,up(t),…,u1(t−M+1),u2(t−M+1),…,up(t−M+1).
The MIMO Volterra tensor consists of l(pM+1)d entries, which can quickly become practically infeasible to store as M and d grow. We therefore propose to store the Volterra tensor V in the TN format V(1),…,V(d), where the first TN-core V(1) has dimensions l×(pM+1)×r1. The other TN-cores have sizes ri−1×(pM+1)×ri, with rd=1 for the last core. The TN format reduces to a TT for the MISO case (l=1). This change in representation reduces the storage requirement to O((d−1)(pM+1)r2+(pM+1)lr). Lemma 2.1 then immediately tells us how to simulate all l output samples at time t as (14)y(t)=(V(1)×2utT)(V(2)×2utT)⋯(V(d)×2utT).The complexity of computing N output samples y(t) is approximately O(dN(pM+1)r2), where r is the maximal TT-rank. In Batselier, Chen, Lui, and Wong (2016) a much faster simulation complexity of O(dRNlogN) for computing N samples is obtained by using a symmetric polyadic representation for each of the Volterra kernels separately. However, the method only works for the SISO case and the identification of such a representation can be problematic, since computation of the canonical rank R is an NP-hard problem (Håstad, 1990), which can be ill-posed (de Silva & Lim, 2008).

4. MIMO Volterra system identification

4.1. Preliminaries

In what follows we always consider the MIMO case. Observe now that we can rewrite (13) as (15)y(t)T=(ut)T(V(1))T,where V(1) is the mode-1 matricization of the Volterra tensor. Writing out (15) for t=0,1,…,N−1 leads to the following matrix equation (16)Y=U(V(1))T,where Y≔y(0)y(1)y(2)⋯y(N−1)T,U≔T.Essentially, MIMO Volterra system identification is in its most basic form solving the matrix equation (16) . This immediately reveals the difficulty, as the size of the U matrix is N×(pM+1)d, which quickly becomes prohibitive even for SISO systems and moderate degree d. This motivates us to solve the following problem.

Problem 1

For a given set of measured input and output signals y1,…,yl,u1,…,up, memory M and degree d, solve the matrix equation (16) for V in the TN format.
Before presenting the two numerical algorithms that solve Problem 1, we first give an upper bound on the rank of U, together with some important implications.

Lemma 4.1

The total number of distinct entries of ut is upper bounded by pM+dpM.
Lemma 4.1 follows from the fact that ut can be interpreted as the vectorization of the symmetric rank-1 tensor obtained from the d-times repeated outer product of ut with itself. The symmetry of the tensor implies that it contains pM+dpM distinct entries. Lemma 4.1 is illustrated in Example 3, where ut∈R27 only has 52=10 distinct entries.

Lemma 4.2

Under the assumption that N≥pM+dpM, the rank of the matrix U is upper bounded by pM+dpM.

Proof

Each row of U consists of (pM+1)d entries formed by the repeated Kronecker product uk for k=1,…,N. From Lemma 4.1 it follows that there are only pM+dpM distinct entries on each row. This implies that there are maximally pM+dpM distinct columns, which fix the upper bound on the total number of linearly independent columns of U.□
Lemma 4.2 motivates us to define a particular set of inputs such that this upper bound is achieved.

Definition 4.1

A set of input signals u1,u2,…,up of length N≥pM+dpM such that rank(U)=pM+dpMis called a set of persistent exciting inputs of order d.
We will from here on always assume that the inputs are persistent exciting and that N≥rank(U). The truncated Volterra series for one particular output is a polynomial in pM variables of degree d and therefore has pM+dpM coefficients. A solution V(1) of the matrix equation (16) that consists of only lpM+dpM distinct entries therefore must correspond with l symmetric tensors, where each column of V(1) corresponds with one particular d-way symmetric tensor. As a result, persistent exciting inputs and sufficient number of samples N together with Lemma 4.2 has the following consequences.

Proposition 4.1

The identification problem (16)has an infinite number of solutions.

Proof

As the total number of columns of U is q≔(pM+1)d and its rank r≔pM+dpM, it follows that there is a q−r-dimensional nullspace. Each column of the general solution of (16) is then v=vLS+Nz,where vLS is the least-squares solution, N is a basis for the nullspace of U and z is any vector in Rq−r. By varying z over Rq−r one obtains infinitely many solutions. One can obtain the minimal 2-norm solution as the least-squares solution vLS by setting z=0.□

Proposition 4.2

The l unique minimal norm solutions of (16)correspond with l symmetric tensors.

Proof

To explain the reasoning behind this consequence, let us consider the SISO d=3,M=2 example from Example 3. Suppose we have a nonsymmetric solution v. We can “symmetrize” v by considering repeated entries of ut and averaging the corresponding entries of v. For example, the entry u(t) appears as the second, fourth and tenth entry of ut. The corresponding entries of the symmetric solution ṽ are then (v2+v4+v10)∕3. We now need to compare ‖v‖22 with ‖ṽ‖22. One can now see that ‖ṽ‖22≤‖v‖22 since v22+v42+v102≥3(v2+v4+v10)∕32. Equality only holds when v corresponds with a symmetric tensor, viz. v2=v4=v10.  □

Proposition 4.3

The unicity of the symmetric solutions implies that no other symmetric solutions exist.

Proof

A symmetric solution has a minimal 2-norm and therefore corresponds with the unique least-squares solution. Therefore there are no other symmetric solutions.   □

Proposition 4.4

Any solution V(1) of (16)can be turned into l minimal norm solutions by symmetrizing each of the tensors given by the columns of V(1).

Proof

Knowing that the minimal norm solution is also the symmetric solution provides a recipe on how to obtain vLS from any general solution v by “symmetrization”. The symmetrization process has already been alluded to in the second consequence and involves an averaging of the entries over all index permutations.   □
The consequences mentioned above indicate that Problem 1 is actually ill-posed, as it has an infinite amount of solutions. Ideally, one would solve (16) for the minimal norm solutions as argminX‖UX−Y‖F+λ2‖X‖F,where ‖⋅‖F denotes the Frobenius norm. The extra λ2‖X‖F term acts to regularize the problem such that its solution is uniquely defined. The two iterative methods which we describe in the next subsections do not guarantee convergence to the minimal norm solutions. In practice, it is not a good idea to emphasize minimizing ‖UX−Y‖F as much as possible. This is known in the machine learning community as overfitting, which typically results in very poor generalization power of the identified model. As will be illustrated in Section 5, overfitting corresponds in our TN-framework with solutions that exhibit relatively large TN-ranks.

4.2. Alternating linear scheme method

The first method that we derive is the Alternating Linear Scheme (ALS) method. The key idea of this method is to fix the TN-ranks r1,r2,…,rd−1 and choose a particular initial guess for V(1),…,V(d). Each of the TN-cores is then updated separately in an iterative fashion until convergence has been reached. Once the core V(d) is updated, the algorithm “sweeps” back towards V(1) and so on. It turns out that updating one of the cores is equivalent with solving a much smaller linear system, which can be done very efficiently. Before describing the form of the reduced linear system, we first introduce the following notation vk−1≔(V(1)×2utT)⋯(V(k−1)×2utT)∈Rl×rk−1,vk+1≔(V(k+1)×2utT)⋯(V(d)×2utT)∈Rrk×1.

Theorem 4.1

For outputs y1,…,yl described by a MIMO Volterra system (14)we have that (17)y(t)=(vk+1T⊗utT⊗vk−1)vec(V(k)).

Proof

We first rewrite (14) as y(t)=vk−1(V(k)×2utT)vk+1.This equation holds since it is the product of the l×rk−1 matrix vk−1 with the rk−1×rk matrix (V(k)×2utT) with the rk×1 vector vk+1, resulting in the l×1 vector y(t). We then have that y(t)=vk−1(V(k)×2utT)vk+1,=(vk+1T⊗vk−1)vec(V(k)×2utT),=(vk+1T⊗vk−1)vec(V(k)×1Irk−1×2utT×3Irk),=(vk+1T⊗vk−1)(Irk⊗utT⊗Irk−1)vec(V(k)),=(vk+1T⊗1⊗vk−1)(Irk⊗utT⊗Irk−1)vec(V(k)),=(vk+1T⊗utT⊗vk−1)vec(V(k)),where the second equation is obtained from (8), the fourth equation is obtained from using (6) and the final equation follows from (5). This concludes the proof.   □
The importance of Theorem 4.1 lies in the fact that it describes how the reduced linear system to update V(k) can be constructed. Indeed, suppose we want to update V(k) and keep all other TN-cores fixed. By using Eq. (17) for t=0,…,N−1 the following linear system is obtained (18)vec(YT)=Ukvec(V(k)),where Uk is a lN×rk−1(pM+1)rk matrix. Next to the obvious savings in computational complexity compared to solving Eq. (16), this effectively requires much fewer samples N to perform the identification. Indeed, one only has to make sure that lN≥rk−1(pM+1)rk. Computing the minimal norm solution of Eq. (18) requires the computation of the pseudo-inverse of Uk, which requires O(4Nl(rk−1(pM+1)rk)2+8(rk−1(pM+1)rk)3) computations.
Numerical stability of the ALS algorithm is guaranteed by the use of an orthogonalization step (Holtz et al., 2012 p. A690). The key idea is that all TN-cores are initialized to be right orthogonal and are kept orthogonal during each step. After updating V(1) by solving (18), this tensor is reshaped into a r0(pM+1)×r1 matrix from which a thin QR decomposition (Golub & Van Loan, 1996 p. 230) is computed. This takes O(2l(pM+1)r12+2r13∕2) flops. The orthogonal matrix Q is then chosen as a new left orthogonal V(1) TN-core, since QTQ=Ir1. The corresponding R matrix is then absorbed into the V(2) core by reshaping the core into a r1×(pM+1)r2 matrix V2 and computing RV2. Next, V(2) is updated and orthogonalized, after which V(3) is updated and so forth. When the iterative “sweep” has reached the end of the TN, it reverses direction and in a similar way all cores are made right orthogonal by QR decompositions. The whole algorithm is presented as pseudocode in Algorithm 1. A Matlab/Octave implementation of Algorithm 1 can be freely downloaded from https://github.com/kbatseli/MVMALS. A few remarks on the ALS method:
  • •
    Choosing TN-ranks r1,…,rd−1 smaller than their canonical values results in finding an approximation to the Volterra tensor V, which implies that only an approximation of the solution for (16) is found.
  • •
    The iterations can be terminated when the solution does not exhibit any further improvement or when a certain fixed maximal number of sweeps has been executed. In our implementation we set a tolerance on the relative residual ‖Y−Yˆ‖F∕‖Y‖F, where Yˆ is the simulated output from the obtained solution.
  • •
    It is proved in Holtz et al. (2012) and Rohwedder and Uschmajew (2013) that under certain conditions the ALS method enjoys strictly monotonous convergence. Convergence to the unique minimal norm solutions cannot be guaranteed however.
  • •
    Also in Holtz et al., (2012, p. A701), it is proved that the QR decomposition step ensures that the condition number of each Uk matrix in (18) is upper bounded by the condition number of the large U matrix. This ensures the numerical stability of the ALS method.
While the ALS method has a small computational complexity, it suffers from the problem that all TN-ranks need to be specified a priori. Finding a good choice can be quite difficult when d is large. Theorem 2.1 should be kept in mind when choosing TN-ranks, as it is not meaningful to specify TN-ranks larger than their upper bounds. This difficulty in finding good TN-ranks is the main motivation for the development of the Modified Alternating Linear Scheme (MALS) algorithm, which not only updates the TN-cores but also adapts the TN-ranks during each step. An additional benefit is that the TN-cores are guaranteed to be either left or right orthogonal so that no stabilizing QR step is required anymore. These benefits, however, come at the cost of a higher computational complexity.

4.3. Modified alternating linear scheme method

The main idea of the MALS is in fact a simple one, namely, to update two TN-cores V(k),V(k+1) at a time by considering them as one “super-core” and keeping all other cores fixed. The updated super-core is then decomposed into one orthogonal and one non-orthogonal part, which are used as updates for both V(k) and V(k+1). This decomposition step is achieved by computing a singular value decomposition (SVD) and it is here where the TN-rank rk is updated. This updating procedure is repeated in the same sweeping fashion as with the ALS method until the solution has converged. We now derive the reduced linear system for computing a new super-core. The entries of the super-core V(k,k+1) are defined as the contraction of V(k) with V(k+1) by summing over all possible rk values Vi1[i2i3]i4(k,k+1)=∑j=1rkVi1i2j(k)Vji3i4(k+1).The square brackets around i2i3 indicate that these indices need to be interpreted as one single multi-index such that V(k,k+1) is an rk−1×(pM+1)2×rk+1 3-way tensor. Observe that the formation of the super-core has removed all information on rk. It is now straightforward to verify that (V(k)×2utT)(V(k+1)×2utT)=V(k,k+1)×2(utT)holds. Using the same notation as in the ALS method we now derive the reduced linear system for the MALS.

Theorem 4.2

For outputs y1,…,yl described by a MIMO Volterra system (14)we have that (19)y(t)=(vk+2T⊗(utT)⊗vk−1)vec(V(k,k+1)).

Proof

By rewriting (14) this time as y(t)=vk−1(V(k,k+1)×2(utT))vk+2,it can be clearly seen that the rest of the proof is now identical to the ALS case.   □
Application of Theorem 4.2 for t=0,…,N−1 now results in the reduced linear system (20)vec(YT)=Uk,k+1vec(V(k,k+1)),where Uk,k+1 is an lN×rk−1(pM+1)2rk+1 matrix. The minimal norm solution of (20) can by computed in O(4Nl(rk−1(pM+1)2rk+1)2+8(rk−1(pM+1)2rk+1)3) flops. Once the new super-core has been computed, it can be reshaped into an rk−1(pM+1)×(pM+1)rk+1 matrix Vk,k+1. The SVD of Vk,k+1 is Vk,k+1=USVT,where U,V are orthogonal matrices and S is a diagonal matrix with positive entries s1≥⋯≥sq, with q=min(rk−1(pM+1),(pM+1)rk+1). Its computation requires O(4(rk−12(pM+1)3rk+1)+8(rk−1(pM+1)3rk+1)2+9((pM+1)3rk+13)) flops. The numerical rank rk can be determined from a given tolerance τ such that s1≥⋯≥srk≥τ≥⋯≥sq. If the sweep is going from left to right then we update V(k),V(k+1) as V(k)≔reshape(U,[rk−1,(pM+1),rk]),V(k+1)≔reshape(SVT,[rk,(pM+1),rk+1]),which makes V(k) left orthogonal. If the sweep is going from right to left then the updates are V(k)≔reshape(US,[rk−1,(pM+1),rk]),V(k+1)≔reshape(VT,[rk,(pM+1),rk+1]),where now V(k+1) is right orthogonal. The pseudocode for the MALS algorithm is given in Algorithm 2. A Matlab/Octave implementation of Algorithm 2 can also be freely downloaded from https://github.com/kbatseli/MVMALS. The same remarks on the stopping criterion, numerical stability and convergence as in the ALS case apply here. The tolerance τ for the determination of the numerical rank rk can be chosen such that the error is below a certain threshold. In our implementation we opted for the default choice in Matlab/Octave, which is τ=ϵs1max(ri−1(pM+1),(pM+1)ri+1), where ϵ is the machine precision. If the tolerance on the obtained solution is set too low then the MALS algorithm will have the tendency to increase the TN-ranks to very high values, resulting in higher computational complexity. However, it does not make sense in system identification to require that the solution interpolates the measured output to a high accuracy (say up to the machine precision), which is essentially overfitting.

5. Numerical experiments

In this section we demonstrate the two proposed identification algorithms. All computations were done on an Intel i5 quad-core processor running at 3.3 GHz with 16 GB RAM. We are not aware of any other publicly available algorithms that are able to identify high-degree MIMO Volterra systems, say, at d=10.

5.1. Decaying multi-dimensional exponentials

First, we demonstrate the validity of Algorithms 1 and 2 by means of an artificial SISO example. Symmetric Volterra kernels were generated up to degree d=10 for a fixed memory M=7 and containing exponentially decaying coefficients. The ith symmetric Volterra kernel hi contains the entries hi(k1,…,ki)=exp−0.1∑j=1ikj2.Each of the ki indices attains the values 0,1,2,…,6. For each degree d a random input signal of 5000 samples, uniformly distributed over the interval [0,1], was generated. The Volterra kernel was estimated by solving (16) directly using the pseudoinverse of U where possible. The MALS algorithm was used to determine a solution for which ‖y−yˆ‖2∕‖y‖2<1e−4 was satisfied. The TT-ranks determined by the MALS algorithm were then used to determine a solution with the same relative accuracy using the ALS method. Both the MALS and ALS algorithms always ran with the first 700 samples of the input and output. Table 1 lists the run times in seconds for the three methods, the maximal TT-rank and the total number of identified Volterra kernel elements for each degree. Starting from degree d=5 it was not possible anymore to obtain the Volterra tensor directly since this would require the inversion of a 32 768 × 32 768 matrix. From d=3, the maximal TT-rank stabilizes to 8 for all TT-cores. Even though the ALS method exhibits low computational complexity, its convergence is much slower than MALS, resulting in larger run times. The obtained solutions were validated by simulating the output using the 4300 remaining input points. Fig. 2 shows both the real and simulated output from the MALS solution for samples 1640 up to 1700. The two output signals are almost indistinguishable. No difference between the ALS and MALS solutions could be observed.

5.2. Choosing the TN-ranks

This experiment illustrates how the TN-ranks affect the estimated Volterra model. The user has to choose particular values of the TN-ranks when using the ALS algorithm, considering the upper bounds of Theorem 2.1. In practice however, one would never want to choose the ranks to attain these upper bounds. The reasons for this are twofold. First, for high-order tensors with large dimensions, the upper bounds will become prohibitively large. Second, higher TN-ranks result in models that tend to fit the training data better but perform poorly on new validation data. Here, we consider a 3-input-2-output Volterra system with degree d=3 and memory M=3 that has a TN-representation with TN-ranks r1=11,r2=10. The upper bounds for a general 3-input-2-output Volterra system with d=3,M=3 are r1≤20,r2≤10. Standard normal white noise inputs of length N=2000 were used to compute the outputs. Volterra models with d=3,M=3 and increasing TN-ranks were then estimated using the ALS algorithm from the first 700 samples of the input–output data. Table 2 lists both the relative training and validation errors ‖y(t)−yˆ(t)‖∕‖y(t)‖ for the different TN-ranks, where yˆ(t) is the simulated output. One can see a steady decrease of both errors and when the TN-ranks are chosen to attain their true values, both errors drop to the machine precision. Further increase of r1 does not improve the validation error any further. The MALS algorithm identifies a Volterra model where the TN-ranks attain their upper bounds, indicating that the ALS algorithm may be more useful in practice to obtain more simple models without the loss of predictive power. This, however, comes at the cost of having to manually find good values of the TN-ranks.

5.3. Comparison with Volterra-PARAFAC identification

The Volterra-PARAFAC model uses a symmetric polyadic decomposition for each of the homogeneous Volterra kernels separately (Favier et al., 2012). This results in a low parametric complexity and relatively simple computations to simulate the model. Note that this model only works for the SISO case. In Favier et al. (2012), three adaptive algorithms are discussed to estimate the factor matrices for all the homogeneous kernels from input–output data. The Extended Complex Kalman filter (ECKF) algorithm is shown to have the best convergence. We implemented the ECKF algorithm in Matlab, as we were unable to obtain the implementation from the authors. This implementation can also be freely downloaded from https://github.com/kbatseli/MVMALS. The factor matrices of a Volterra-PARAFAC system of d=5 and M=6 were drawn from a standard normal distribution. The tensor-ranks of each of the homogeneous Volterra kernels were chosen to be 5. The whole Volterra-PARAFAC model is described by 106 numbers. The output was then computed from 5000 samples of a standard normal white noise input. Additional measurement noise with a standard deviation of σe=10−6 was added to the output signal. The ECKF algorithm also requires the user to choose the covariance α of the initial estimate of all the factor matrices and a forgetting factor λ. These were set to α=1 and λ=1000. The filter was then run over 4700 samples, after which the current values of the estimated factor matrices were used to simulate the remaining 300 samples. The relative validation error obtained from the simulated output was 1.3270. A M=6,d=5 TT-based Volterra model was also identified with the ALS algorithm from the first 700 samples. All TT-ranks were set to 7, which means the TT is described by 1127 numbers. The relative error of the simulated output from the remaining 4300 samples was 0.0024. Fig. 3 shows the true output and the simulated outputs from both identified models for the samples 4800 up to 4819.

5.4. Double balanced mixer

In this example we consider a double balanced mixer used for upconversion (Rubiola, 2006). The reason this particular example was chosen is because it is not a weakly-nonlinear system and therefore cannot be reasonably approximated by a low-order Volterra system. The output radio-frequency (RF) signal is determined by a 100 Hz sine low-frequency (LO) signal and a 300 Hz square-wave intermediate-frequency (IF) signal. A phase difference of π∕8 is present between the LO and IF signals. All time series were sampled at 5 kHz for 1 s. We investigate the effect of additive output noise on the identified models. We define 5 different noise levels which are added to the measured RF output, generating signals with signal-to-noise (SNR) ratios ranging from 11dB up to 25dB. The first 700 samples of the inputs and the noisy output are then used to identify an M=2,d=11 two-input one-output Volterra system using the ALS method. The MIMO Volterra tensor consists in this case of 48 828 125 entries. The TN-ranks are all fixed to 2M+1=5. The identified models were then used to simulate the remaining 4300 samples of the output. The SNR of the simulated output was computed by comparing the simulated output with the original noiseless output. Table 3 lists the SNR of the signals used in the identification (ID SNR), the relative residual of the simulated output, the run time of the identification in seconds and the SNR of the simulated signal (SIM SNR). The SNR of the simulated output is defined as 10log10∑iy(i)2∑i(y(i)−yˆ(i))2where y(i) is the output signal uncorrupted by noise and yˆ(i) is the simulated output. As expected, a gradual improvement of the relative residual can be seen as the SNR of the signals used for identification increases. Although the residual remains high throughout the different SNR levels, the SNR of the simulated output is much better, with a consistent increase of 11 dB. The run time varies between 2 and 6 s. Fig. 4 shows the simulated output on the validation data for three Volterra models identified under three different SNR levels (11 dB, 16 dB, 25 dB).
Next, the MALS algorithm was run on the same data to also identify M=2,d=11 Volterra models. Based on the ALS results we set the tolerance on the relative residual to 0.5. This resulted in all TN-ranks being 5 for all cases. Table 4 lists the SNR of the signals used in the identification (ID SNR), the relative residual of the simulated output, the run time of the identification in seconds and the SNR of the simulated signal (SIM SNR). The relative residuals and SNRs of the simulated output are very close to the results obtained by the ALS identification. Just as in Section 5.1, MALS is able to finish the identification faster than the ALS method. Furthermore, the run time does not vary as much as in the ALS case. Lowering the tolerance for the data with low SNR resulted in the MALS method increasing the TN ranks significantly, up to the point that the 5000 samples were not sufficient anymore. This indicates a tendency of the MALS method to overfit.

6. Conclusions

This article presented two new and remarkably efficient identification algorithms for high-order MIMO Volterra systems. The identification problem was rephrased in terms of the Volterra tensor, which is never explicitly constructed but instead always stored in the highly economic TN format. Both proposed identification algorithms are iterative, starting from an initial orthogonal guess for the TN-cores and updating them until a desired accuracy is acquired. The algorithms are guaranteed to monotonically converge and numerical stability is ensured by retaining orthogonality in the TN-cores. The efficiency of both identification algorithms was demonstrated by numerical examples, where reliable MIMO Volterra systems of degrees 10 were estimated in only a few seconds. Even though its computational complexity is lower, the ALS method was found to converge slower than the MALS algorithm when producing solutions with the same accuracy. The MALS method showed a tendency to increase the TN-ranks under the presence of high noise levels. Extending the robustness of these methods to noisy data will be the subject of further research. Furthermore, one anonymous reviewer posed the interesting future research topic of developing a method for the generation of persistent exciting input signals for the identification of high degree MIMO Volterra systems.

  • Parameter estimation for nonlinear Volterra systems by using the multi-innovation identification theory and tensor decomposition

    2022, Journal of the Franklin Institute
    Citation Excerpt :

    Another one is to develop Volterra kernels on the orthogonal basis functions or represent these parameters as a tensor decomposition to obtain the reduced complexity Volterra models. There are many results show that tensor decompositions are a useful paradigm to lift the curse of dimensionality in the identification of the nonlinear Volterra models [31–33]. The algorithms based on the mean square error for Gaussian noise environments often perform poorly when the noise is non-Gaussian and/or impulsive.

    The Volterra model can represent a wide range of nonlinear dynamical systems. However, its practical use in nonlinear system identification is limited due to the exponentially growing number of Volterra kernel coefficients as the degree increases. This paper considers the identification issue of discrete-time nonlinear Volterra systems and uses a tensorial decomposition called PARAFAC to represent the Volterra kernels which can provide a significant parametric reduction compared with the conventional Volterra model. Applying the multi-innovation identification theory, the recursive algorithm by combining the l2-norm is proposed for the PARAFAC-Volterra models with the Gaussian noises. In addition, the multi-innovation algorithm combining with the logarithmic p-norms is investigated for the nonlinear Volterra systems with the non-Gaussian noises. Finally, some simulation results illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed identification methods.

  • Matrix output extension of the tensor network Kalman filter with an application in MIMO Volterra system identification

    2018, Automatica
    This article extends the tensor network Kalman filter to matrix outputs with an application in recursive identification of discrete-time nonlinear multiple-input-multiple-output (MIMO) Volterra systems. This extension completely supersedes previous work, where only l scalar outputs were considered. The Kalman tensor equations are modified to accommodate for matrix outputs and their implementation using tensor networks is discussed. The MIMO Volterra system identification application requires the conversion of the output model matrix with a row-wise Kronecker product structure into its corresponding tensor network, for which we propose an efficient algorithm. Numerical experiments demonstrate both the efficacy of the proposed matrix conversion algorithm and the improved convergence of the Volterra kernel estimates when using matrix outputs.

  • Tensor network subspace identification of polynomial state space models

    2018, Automatica
    This article introduces a tensor network subspace algorithm for the identification of specific polynomial state space models. The polynomial nonlinearity in the state space model is completely written in terms of a tensor network, thus avoiding the curse of dimensionality. We also prove how the block Hankel data matrices in the subspace method can be exactly represented by low rank tensor networks, reducing the computational and storage complexity significantly. The performance and accuracy of our subspace identification algorithm are illustrated by experiments, showing that our tensor network implementation identifies a seventh degree polynomial state space model around 20 times faster than the standard matrix implementation before the latter fails due to insufficient memory. The proposed algorithm is also robust with respect to noise and therefore applicable to practical systems.

  • Filtering-based recursive least squares estimation approaches for multivariate equation-error systems by using the multiinnovation theory

    2021, International Journal of Adaptive Control and Signal Processing

  • Fast and Accurate Tensor Completion with Total Variation Regularized Tensor Trains

    2020, IEEE Transactions on Image Processing

  • Computing low-rank approximations of large-scale matrices with the tensor network randomized SVD

    2018, SIAM Journal on Matrix Analysis and Applications

Kim Batselier received the M.S. degree in Electro-Mechanical Engineering and the Ph.D. Degree in Applied Sciences from the KU Leuven, in 2005 and 2013 respectively. He worked as a research engineer at BioRICS on automated performance monitoring until 2009. He is currently a Post-Doctoral Research Fellow at The University of Hong Kong since 2013. His current research interests include linear and nonlinear system theory/identification, algebraic geometry, tensors, and numerical algorithms.
